private_information: I can manipulate only vowel-labelled blocks: A, E, I.
I can only move blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move only one block at a time.
vowel_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks so that A is on B, B is on C, C is on D, D is on E, E is on F, F is on G, G is on H, H is on I, I is on J, and J is on the table.

private_information: I can manipulate only consonant-labelled blocks: B, C, D, F, G, H, J.
I can only move blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move only one block at a time.
consonant_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks so that A is on B, B is on C, C is on D, D is on E, E is on F, F is on G, G is on H, H is on I, I is on J, and J is on the table.

orchestrator.goal: Produce a single PDDL domain and PDDL problem compatible with the FastDownwards solver that achieves the block stacking goal while keeping the agents' action capabilities distinct.

public_information: There are ten uniquely labelled blocks: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J.
Only the top block of any stack can be moved by an agent.
Each agent may move only one block at a time.
One agent is restricted to manipulating vowel-labelled blocks. The other agent is restricted to manipulating consonant-labelled blocks.
Initial configuration: G is on the table.
Initial configuration: B is on the table.
Initial configuration: C is on the table.
Initial configuration: F is on top of G.
Initial configuration: H is on top of C.
Initial configuration: I is on top of B.
Initial configuration: J is on top of H.
Initial configuration: D is on top of J.
Initial configuration: E is on top of I.
Initial configuration: A is on top of F.
Goal configuration: A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on the table.

perceive.system_prompt: You are vowel_agent. Use the public information and your private knowledge to report which vowel blocks you can legally move right now and any constraints you observe. Provide a concise structured observation describing top-of-stack vowel blocks, whether they are clear, and suggested safe intermediate placements if relevant.
perceive.prompt: You are vowel_agent. Consider the environment public information and your private information. Produce a concise structured observation of the vowel blocks you may move and relevant constraints. Do not emit PDDL.

perceive.system_prompt: You are consonant_agent. Use the public information and your private knowledge to report which consonant blocks you can legally move right now and any constraints you observe. Provide a concise structured observation describing top-of-stack consonant blocks, whether they are clear, and suggested safe intermediate placements if relevant.
perceive.prompt: You are consonant_agent. Consider the environment public information and your private information. Produce a concise structured observation of the consonant blocks you may move and relevant constraints. Do not emit PDDL.

pddl.system_prompt: You are orchestrator. Integrate the observations from both agents and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem targeting the FastDownwards solver. Keep the agents' actions distinct by prefixing or naming actions to indicate which agent can perform them. Model the block world with predicates that express on, ontable, clear, and holding or arm state as appropriate. Encode action preconditions so that only top blocks can be moved and so that vowel_agent actions are applicable only to vowel blocks and consonant_agent actions only to consonant blocks. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain> and </domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem> and </problem>. Ensure the PDDL is syntactically compatible with FastDownwards and declares objects, initial state, and goal as required.
pddl.prompt: You are orchestrator. Use the structured observations obs_vowel and obs_consonant to fill any necessary details. Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that, when given to FastDownwards, will achieve the goal stacking A on B on C on D on E on F on G on H on I on J on table. Keep agent actions distinct. Enclose the domain within <domain></domain> tags and the problem within <problem></problem> tags.
